{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3505381,"name":"kuzey","username":"kuzeyatay","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/59ef9b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-07T20:41:21.849Z","cooked":"

We just built our elevator but there is an issue with our motors reaching the setpoint. after reaching the setpoint the elevator moves down and when reset to home position and run again the elevator moves less than it originally does(and moves down again) i have provided a picture to better illustrate the problem. Also heres the github link to my code:

github.com

2025-Robot-Code/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems at main ·...

Team 9247 Reefscape robot code. Contribute to kuzeyatay/2025-Robot-Code development by creating an account on GitHub.

Any help would be grately appreciated!

PS: We dont use any absolute encoder.

IMG_88544032×3024 3.17 MB

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-02-07T20:59:12.202Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":50,"reads":174,"readers_count":173,"score":284.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485588,"topic_slug":"elevator-acting-weird-overshooting","display_username":"kuzey","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/kuzeyatay/2025-Robot-Code/tree/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"2025-Robot-Code/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems at main · kuzeyatay/2025-Robot-Code · GitHub","clicks":9}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61536,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-acting-weird-overshooting/485588/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3505419,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-07T21:16:47.199Z","cooked":"

Some guesses:

The difference between starting points at the bottom of the travel could be the difference between first starting by somehow manually setting the mechanism at the bottom vs the subsequent runs of the mechanism being driven more powerfully by the motor into the hard-stop.

The difference between the spikey peaks and the somewhat lower plateaus looks like the tolerance sag allowed the controller.

The difference between the first top position and subsequent ones could be taking up backlash or stretch.

It is interesting that the first run settles at about the same place the subsequent runs go to then sag. That could be an important part of the explanation of differences - larger overshoot the first time and the rest are good. Maybe it’s the backlash or stretch.

how can we fix these issues you have mentioned

Can you share more photos of the mechanical side of things? Like @SLAB-Mr.Thomas mentioned, it could be due to slack/stretch somewhere in your system.

Are you using any sort of spool to wind up/unwind a cable or rope to power your elevator up and down?

More photos of the gearbox, pulleys, etc would all be helpful!

I may have missed it in your code, but did you add a tolerance for your PID controller when targeting a setpoint?

I did not add a tolerance for the pid controller. However i highly think its the slack in our spool system. Trying to fix it now and will keep you updated!
